title: Initial Setup
description: Items in this section are advised for all systems but may be difficult or require extensive preparation after the initial setup of the system.

children.title: Filesystem
children.description: The file system is generally a built-in layer used to handle the data management of the storage

children.title: Configure Filesystem Kernel Modules
children.description: A number of uncommon filesystem types are supported under Linux. Removing support for unneeded filesystem types reduces the local attack surface of the system. If a filesystem type is not needed it should be disabled. Native Linux file systems are designed to ensure that built-in security controls function as expected. Non-native filesystems can lead to unexpected consequences to both the security and functionality of the system and should be used with caution. Many filesystems are created for niche use cases and are not maintained and supported as the operating systems are updated and patched. Users of non-native filesystems should ensure that there is attention and ongoing support for them, especially in light of frequent operating system changes. Standard network connectivity and Internet access to cloud storage may make the use of non-standard filesystem formats to directly attach heterogeneous devices much less attractive

children.title: Ensure cramfs kernel module is not available
children.description: The cramfs filesystem is a compressed read-only filesystem that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.title: Ensure freevxfs kernel module is not available
children.description: The freevxfs filesystem is a read-only filesystem that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.title: Ensure hfs kernel module is not available
children.description: The hfs filesystem is an older filesystem used primarily by Apple systems and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.title: Ensure hfsplus kernel module is not available
children.description: The hfsplus filesystem is an updated version of the hfs filesystem used by Apple systems and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.title: Ensure jffs2 kernel module is not available
children.description: The jffs2 filesystem is a journaling flash filesystem that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.title: Ensure squashfs kernel module is not available
children.description: The squashfs filesystem is a compressed read-only filesystem that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.title: Ensure udf kernel module is not available
children.description: The udf filesystem is a universal disk format that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.title: Ensure usb-storage kernel module is not available
children.description: The usb-storage kernel module allows the system to access USB storage devices. If USB storage is not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.title: Configure Filesystem Partitions
children.description: Partitioning the filesystem can enhance security by isolating critical directories and preventing unauthorized access to sensitive data. It also helps in managing disk space more effectively.

children.title: Configure /tmp
children.description: The /tmp directory is used for temporary file storage. Configuring it as a separate partition can prevent unauthorized access and ensure that temporary files do not consume space on the root filesystem.

children.title: Ensure /tmp is separate partition
children.description: Having /tmp as a separate partition can help prevent unauthorized access to temporary files and ensure that the root filesystem is not filled with temporary data.

children.title: Ensure nodev option set on /tmp partition
children.description: The nodev option prevents the creation of device files in the /tmp directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.title: Ensure nosuid option is set on /tmp partition
children.description: The nosuid option prevents the execution of setuid and setgid programs in the /tmp directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.title: Ensure noexec option is set on /tmp partition
children.description: The noexec option prevents the execution of binaries in the /tmp directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.title: Configure /dev/shm
children.description: The /dev/shm directory is used for shared memory. Configuring it as a separate partition can enhance security by isolating shared memory from other filesystems.

children.title: Verify /dev/shm is mounted as a separate partition
children.description: Having /dev/shm as a separate partition can help prevent unauthorized access to shared memory and ensure that it does not consume space on the root filesystem.

children.title: Ensure nodev option is set on /dev/shm partition

children.title: Ensure nosuid option is set on /dev/shm partition

children.title: Ensure noexec option set on /dev/shm partition

children.title: Package Management
children.description: Package management is a critical aspect of system security, ensuring that the software installed on the system is up-to-date and free from known vulnerabilities. This section provides guidance on how to manage packages effectively, including installing, updating, and removing software packages.

children.title: Configure Package Repositories
children.description: Configuring package repositories ensures that the system can access trusted sources for software packages, reducing the risk of installing malicious or outdated software.

children.title: Ensure GPG keys are configured
children.description: GPG keys are used to verify the authenticity of packages. Ensuring that GPG keys are configured helps prevent the installation of tampered or malicious packages.

children.title: Ensure package manager repositories are configured
children.description: Configuring package manager repositories ensures that the system can access trusted sources for software packages, reducing the risk of installing malicious or outdated software.

children.title: Configure Packege Updates
children.description: Configuring package updates ensures that the system is kept up-to-date with the latest security patches and software improvements, reducing the risk of vulnerabilities.

children.title: Ensure updates, patches, and additional security software are installed
children.description: Regularly installing updates, patches, and additional security software helps keep the system secure against known vulnerabilities.

children.title: Mandatory Access Control
children.description: Mandatory Access Control (MAC) is a security mechanism that restricts the ability of users and processes to access system resources based on predefined policies. This section provides guidance on how to implement and configure MAC systems to enhance security.

children.title: Configure AppArmor
children.description: AppArmor is a Linux kernel security module that allows the system administrator to restrict programs' capabilities with per-program profiles. Configuring AppArmor enhances security by limiting the actions that programs can perform.

children.title: Ensure AppArmor is installed
children.description: AppArmor must be installed to provide mandatory access control for applications. It helps in confining programs to a limited set of resources and capabilities.

children.title: Ensure AppArmor is enabled in the bootloader configuration
children.description: Enabling AppArmor in the bootloader configuration ensures that it is activated during system startup, providing mandatory access control from the beginning.

children.title: Ensure AppArmor profiles are in enforce mode
children.description: AppArmor profiles define the access rights for applications. Ensuring that profiles are in enforce mode means that the restrictions defined in the profiles are actively enforced, enhancing security.

children.title: Ensure all AppArmor profiles are in enforcing
children.description: Ensuring that all AppArmor profiles are in enforcing mode means that the restrictions defined in the profiles are actively enforced, enhancing security.

title: Services
description: While applying system updates and patches helps correct known vulnerabilities, one of the best ways to protect the system against as yet unreported vulnerabilities is to disable all services that are not required for normal system operation. This prevents the exploitation of vulnerabilities discovered at a later date. If a service is not enabled, it cannot be exploited. The actions in this section of the document provide guidance on some services which can be safely disabled and under which circumstances, greatly reducing the number of possible threats to the resulting system. Additionally, some services which should remain enabled but with secure configuration are covered as well as insecure service clients.

children.title: Configure Server Services
children.description: Server services are essential for the operation of the system and should be configured to ensure security and functionality.
